column2: Religious groups have expressed disappointment at the federal governmentâ€™s decision to shelve controversial religious discrimination laws, claiming parliament lost sight of the original intent of the legislation. Groups such as the Australian National Imams Council (ANIC) have urged the government to return their focus to the initial purpose of the bill, which was to protect religious minorities.  ANIC spokesperson Bilal Rauf told Guardian Australia it was â€œdisappointingâ€ to see the bill delayed, saying there was a â€œsignificant gapâ€ in protective laws. â€œI think the primary focus of this bill was always those protective provisions to bring it in line with the protections based on other attributes â€“ that was always the primary provision and there was no dispute or question about those proposed provisions,â€ he said. â€œThe rest was secondary, and sadly the secondary provisions became the subject of debate. â€œItâ€™s disappointing that it has been shelved, and we hope that itâ€™s something that will quickly be revived and pursued.â€ Rauf said the ANIC supported the bill because there were currently little to no protections for people based on religion. But if itâ€™s a religious activity, the employer can do what they want. â€œAnd this really is the first time that there has been any consideration. So thatâ€™s a welcome shift, that thereâ€™s an acknowledgment that we do need something in circumstances where, for a long time, it wasnâ€™t even an issue in the minds of many.â€ Rauf also emphasised the importance of the vilification amendments that Labor proposed, mentioning that there was also no recourse for people who faced hate speech rooted in religious belief. â€œThere are already some laws there which protect against vilification based on other attributes. Itâ€™s just as important to protect against hate speech based on a personâ€™s religious identity. â€œWe know from direct experience of people in the community that there are many who have had to deal with very acerbic comments based on them wearing the hijab or having a beard or something relating to their religious identity.â€ Abdullah Khan, the president at the Islamic Schools Association of Australia, told the Guardian that Islamic schools generally supported the bill as a means of protection. â€œThese protections are critical,â€ he said. â€œSomething that is missing is the protection against vilification based on religion. Itâ€™s something we wanted to see addressed by the bill, itâ€™s a protection we need.â€ â€œThe intent of Islamic schools is not based on discriminating against students on any level, and this was not just about Islamic schools but protecting the whole community.â€ Ravi Singh, chairman of the Australian Sikh Association, said he supported shelving the bill as it stood, but believed religious discrimination laws should have been introduced 20 years ago. He said his community was confused by the process and debate. â€œItâ€™s frustrating and a little confusing. We did not clearly know what was being protected and who was being discriminated against. It was hard to distinguish in the end who the bill was serving. â€œSome parts of the community, especially the LGBTQ communities, had some serious concerns, as well as people in religious institutions. So a lot of questions were raised, and it looked as if they hadnâ€™t been thought through properly. â€œI think itâ€™s better we take a deep breath and reorganise ourselves to find a better solution for all involved.â€ Singh said measures to address religious discrimination were long overdue. â€œThese protections are especially important for the Sikh and Muslim communities, because we are easily identifiable. Out kids have faced lots of discrimination in schools for their beards and turbans, and I myself have been called all the names under the sun. â€œOverall itâ€™s a good step. It was needed over 20 years ago.â€ Peter Wertheim, the co-chief executive of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, said that the shelving of the bill was â€œpreferableâ€ to it being defeated in the Senate. â€œAlthough the shelving of the religious discrimination bill will disappoint many faith communities who have been hoping to draw a line against the incremental erosion of religious rights and freedoms in Australia, the delay is preferable to the prospect of the bill being defeated in the Senate after a divisive debate. â€œThis issue is too important to the future of our country to be held hostage to an arbitrary electoral timetable.â€ â€œThere are major issues standing in the way of an agreement between the Coalition and Labor on the bill, but only a small number of them, and if more time is needed to arrive at a compromise that most of the country will support, then so be it.â€

column2: The wildly popular online puzzle Wordle has been credited with keeping people across the world sane amid the ravages of the pandemic. She thought to herself: â€œI donâ€™t want to die like this, and I donâ€™t want my kids to hear that their mother was murdered.â€ However, help was at hand, partly thanks to her enthusiasm for Wordle, the viral word game in which players are given six guesses to work out a five-letter word. Thousands of miles away on the west coast the oldest of her two daughters was irritated that her mother had not texted over her Wordle score as she usually did each day. â€œI didnâ€™t send my older daughter a Wordle in the morning. And that was disconcerting to her,â€ Holt told Chicagoâ€™s WBBM. When the concerned siblings tried to reach their mother on her landline only to be told it was disconnected, they enlisted the help of a neighbour. He found no answer at the door despite Holtâ€™s car still being in the drive and called the police. When they went round they heard her shouting â€œIâ€™m here! Iâ€™m here! Iâ€™m here in the basement!â€ and freed her. They also arrested a 32-year-old man in an upstairs bedroom. They believed he had experienced a mental health crisis.

column2: Scott Morrison has moved to clarify his apology to Brittany Higgins following concerns it could affect the trial of the man charged with her alleged rape, stating it was â€œby no means a reflection on the matters before a courtâ€. The prime minister on Tuesday apologised in parliament to Higgins for the â€œterrible things that took placeâ€ during her time working in Canberra. That prompted a rebuke from Warwick Korn, the lawyer representing the man accused of her rape, Bruce Lehrmann.  Korn told News Corp Australia the prime ministerâ€™s comments could reduce the chances of Lehrmann having a fair jury trial. â€œIn light of the complexity, difficulty and importance of the task before any jury already, the behaviour of our prime minister and others in this past 24 hours truly beggars belief,â€ he said. Morrisonâ€™s office subsequently sought to clarify his comments. A spokesperson said on Friday the apology referred generally to â€œthe many terrible experiences Ms Higgins has detailed during her time working at Parliament House and the treatment that she has described receiving whilst working here. He denies the charge, saying no form of sexual activity took place, and the trial is expected to last three to four weeks. column2: As Cressida Dick confirmed she will be leaving Scotland Yard in the coming weeks, those affected by the controversies during her tenure welcomed her resignation. â€œThe first time I dealt with Cressida Dick was in 2012 and since then all she has done in relation to my family is just delay, obstruct and disappoint on a huge level,â€ said Alastair Morgan, who has spent decades campaigning for justice for his murdered brother.  The private detective Daniel Morgan was killed with an axe in a pub car park in Sydenham, south-east London, in 1987. The Met was described as â€œinstitutionally corruptâ€ and Dick was personally censured for obstruction by an independent inquiry. Morgan continued: â€œAlthough I think it is a shame that we are seeing another commissioner disappear under a cloud of smoke, it is necessary. My only anxiety now is who is going to replace her and face the massive job in front of them of rebuilding confidence in the Met.â€ Dick has also faced criticism of failure to act on complaints of institutional sexism and misogyny within the Metâ€™s ranks. When Sarah Everardâ€™s killer, a serving Met officer, was sentenced to a whole-life term in September 2021, the Met leadership was mocked for saying that women who were worried about an officer approaching them could wave down a bus. Dick was also criticised for her handling of a vigil held for Everard which resulted in clashes and arrests. Patsy Stevenson, who was detained, said she was pleased Dick had stepped down. She added, however: â€œWe need to focus as well on this not being a token gesture. This does not fix anything, and I just hope that whoever is in charge next understands that radical change needs to be implemented to fix the systemic issues within the Met.â€ Campaign group Reclaim These Streets, which is bringing a legal challenge against the force over its handling of the vigil, simply tweeted: â€œGood riddance.â€ Meanwhile, the feminist group Sisters Uncut said: â€œCressida Dick is resigning but she is leaving behind an institution that is rotten to the core.â€ Other scandals had included the handling of the murders of sisters Bibaa Henry and Nicole Smallman in a north London park in June 2020. Harriet Wistrich, director of the Centre for Womenâ€™s Justice charity, said: â€œThere were far too many stories of officers accused of violence and abuse still in their jobs, and of whistleblowers victimised instead of listened to.â€ Wistrich said Dick â€œrose to the top of the Met, only to preside over an institution where misogynists, racists and homophobes can hold on to their jobs when they are meant to be tackling crimeâ€. She added: â€œThe problem with Cressida as the first female to rise to the top of the most difficult job in policing is that in order to do so she had to put loyalty to her officers above all else. â€œAny future leader of the Met must be able to listen to victims and be prepared to tackle the culture of misogyny and racism that pervades the underbelly of Met policing.â€ Ricky Waumsley, whose partner Daniel Whitworth was murdered by serial killer Stephen Port, also welcomed Dickâ€™s resignation. He said: â€œWhen I was let down by the Met police because of their blatant homophobia towards the four victims that Stephen Port killed, and the inquest concluded that the Met failures â€˜probablyâ€™ contributed to their deaths, I held Cressida accountable for these failures and made a statement that she should â€˜resign with immediate effectâ€™, so I am glad.â€ The former chief crown prosecutor for north-west England Nazir Afzal said that he took â€œno joyâ€ in calling for Dick to resign on several occasions. He tweeted: â€œShe was an excellent investigator. But she became a human shield for the Govt. The problems in policing are bigger than one personâ€.
